conditions.comments: Only very small deviation of the extraction selectivity for alkali metal picrates from that for iodides observed.
Extraction selectivity for K+ over other alkali metal cations decreases when the aqueous phase anion is changed from I- to Pic-.
Enhancement of the K+ selectivity over other alkali metal cations when the aqueous phase anion is changed from I- to Pic-.
Dramatic change of the separation ability from slight preference of Rb+ and Cs+ over K+ with I- as the anion to appreciable K+/Rb+ and K+/Cs+ selectivity with Pic-.
Separation factors were essentially invariant for this change of anion.
Extraction selectivities of these benzo group-containing CEs decrease when the aqueous phase anion is changed from I- to Pic-.
Extraction selectivities of these benzo group-containing CEs decrease when the aqueous phase anion is changed from I- to Pic-.
Extraction selectivities of these benzo group-containing CEs decrease when the aqueous phase anion is changed from I- to Pic-.
No significant deviation of the extraction selectivities with the anion variation are evident.
No significant deviation of the extraction selectivities with the anion variation are evident.
The “picrate effect” on the separation ability of the ligands for alkali metal cations becomes obvious.
The “picrate effect” on the separation ability of the ligands for alkali metal cations becomes obvious.
Use of Pic- instead of I- as the aqueous phase anion significantly decreased the selectivity of Cs+ separation from the mixture of alkali metal cations.
